page.title: 02History, Thurleigh
page.content: The area has been inhabited since the Iron Age and Roman times. Evidence of this were found during recent archaeological excavations undertaken at Vicarage Green before the new houses were built here, in the form of Roman pottery.The present village did not come into existence until the Saxon period, from where the name originates -'Leah' meaning clearing. Thurleigh is mentioned in the 1086 Domesday Survey. The main part of the village, in Mediaeval times was at Bury Hill, here stood Thurleigh Castle, a classic example of motte and bailey with a large central mound surrounded by courtyards and originally defined by ditches. The castle was a Baron castle ,built without the permission of the King and therefore did not remain long. There are other moated sites also.
